awd_titl_txt: An Arctic Collaboratory for Science, Education, and Outreach
awd_abstract_narration: The Arctic Research Consortium of the United States (ARCUS) is a consortium of universities and institutions engaged in arctic research. ARCUS provides organizational support to researchers, funding agencies, arctic communities and others involved in arctic research. Building on its major accomplishments, through this award ARCUS leads a collaboratory focused on networking, capacity building, increasing stakeholder involvement in the scientific process, disseminating information and providing effective outreach. Specific examples of activities include support for the Interagency Research Policy Committee (IARPC) to engage with stakeholders and develop across agencies collaborations; support for the Arctic Research Support and Logistics program to engage the research community to review program priorities and goals for the next five years; a report from a workshop on Arctic Field Safety Risk Management; facilitation of a network of sea ice modelers and the walrus subsistence community in the Sea Ice for Walrus Outlook. In addition to a number of specific tasks with deliverables, ARCUS provides a moderated email listserve, a newsletter, and undertakes activities that catalyze arctic research collaborations and broadens participation in arctic research.

Overview:

The overarching goal of this project was to advance Arctic research through communication and collaboration activities that cannot be accomplished as effectively by individual researchers, institutions, agencies, or other existing organizations. ARCUS carried out several major categories of tasks, focused on networking and science support, collaborations with Indigenous/traditional knowledge holders, communications and outreach, and support for the Interagency Arctic Research Policy Committee (IARPC). Examples of specific activities and outcomes included:

 

Networking and Science Support:

A diversity of conferences, events, and other activities brought together members of the Arctic research community to share knowledge and advance Arctic research efforts:

  • The Arctic Observing Network Open Science Meeting (AOOSM) gathered over 200 people to present and discuss scientific findings and advances resulting from Arctic observing projects (https://www.searcharcticscience.org/meetings/2015/aoosm).
  • The Arctic Field Safety Risk Management workshop brought together 53 logistics support providers, researchers, risk management experts, and agency representatives to discuss program risk management policies and procedures in Arctic field work (https://www.arcus.org/logistics/2014-workshop).
  • The Polar Technology Conference brought together 82 in-person participants and additional virtual participants for technical and theoretical exchange on challenges impeding polar research and field operations (https://www.arcus.org/logistics/2020-polar-technology).
  • Each year of the award, ARCUS organized Arctic Community Meeting Rooms for use by Arctic Research community members wishing to hold side-meetings alongside the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting. For example, in 2018, the community rooms hosted 34 meetings that were attended by over 440 people (https://www.arcus.org/communitymeetings). 
  • A series of ?Listen and Learn? sessions provided a shared space for students, researchers, and others to discuss challenges in Arctic Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) and how to improve engagement of rural and Alaska Native undergraduates and youth in Arctic STEM (https://www.arcus.org/meetings/2021/arctic-youth-stem).
  • ?Funders Meet & Greet? events provided informal opportunities for Arctic researchers to meet with program officers from funding agencies to gain insight into each organization?s Arctic research interests and opportunities.
  • Anchorage Arctic Research Day open networking events in Anchorage, Alaska were held to share information on Arctic research efforts from a variety of organizations, including academia, industry, government, Indigenous organizations, not-for-profits, and consulting groups.
  • ARCUS provided support for, and collaborated with, the U.S. Interagency Arctic Research Policy Committee (IARPC) Secretariat (https://www.iarpccollaborations.org/index.html), to catalyze the research community to work together on common objectives. 
  • In addition, many other conference sessions and talks were organized to improve collaborations across disciplines and perspectives in Arctic science and education.

Collaboration with Indigenous/Traditional Knowledge Holders:

Several activities focused on collaborations with Indigenous/Traditional Knowledge experts, including:

  • The Sea Ice for Walrus Outlook (SIWO) brought together scientific forecasts and local observations from Alaska Native experts to gain understanding of weather, ice, and wind patterns in the northern Bering Sea and southern Chukchi Sea regions of Alaska (https://www.arcus.org/siwo).
  • The Arctic Indigenous Scholars program, co-led by ARCUS and the Inuit Circumpolar Council (ICC) Alaska, selects Indigenous scholars to travel to Washington, DC, to discuss Arctic issues with DC policy and decision-makers (https://www.arcus.org/indigenous-scholars).
  • ARCUS hosted and mentored Alaska Native Science and Engineering Program (ANSEP; https://www.ansep.net) students to build capacity for the next generation of the Arctic workforce.
  • ARCUS developed an online webpage of resources and best practices for researchers working with northern communities. This curated list of documents, webpages, and other resources was developed with input from the Inuit Circumpolar Council Alaska, Kawerak, Aleutian Pribilof Islands Association, and UIC Science (https://www.arcus.org/resources/northern-communities)

Communication Activities & Tools:

Several tools and activities have disseminated Arctic research to a broad audience, including:

  • Mailing lists and newsletter - ARCUS curated and published announcements for the ArcticInfo mailing list (https://www.arcus.org/arctic-info), the primary email list for the Arctic research community with over 4,800 subscribers and 300?400 curated announcements posted per year; subscribers are approximately 2/3 from the U.S. and 1/3 from 40 other countries. ARCUS also managed the Polar Education List (https://www.arcus.org/education/educationlist), an email discussion list for polar science education with over 1,600 subscribers.
  • The Witness the Arctic online newsletter, with over 8,800 subscribers, provided a reliable source for Arctic research projects, activities, and other news (https://www.arcus.org/witness-the-arctic).
  • The Arctic Research Seminar/Webinar Series provided opportunities for a diverse group of Arctic researchers and community leaders to discuss their work across a broad range of topics and disciplines (https://www.arcus.org/research-seminar-series).
  • The ARCUS website provided essential information for the distributed Arctic research community and hosts information on all tasks under this award, with over 10,000 separate files and over 20,000 photos and resources. Over the course of the award, the website had over 1.3 million page views by 608,573 unique visitors from over 200 countries (https://www.arcus.org).

The activities supported through this award have led to stronger connections and collaborations between disciplines, individuals, groups, and institutions, and has disseminated Arctic research to a broad audience to highlight its relevance and broader value to society.
